sentences.sentence: Law and disorder Christian Porter's reputation is damaged.
But the argument that mere accusations make him unfit for office is a circular one without merit.There is no doubt that Christian Porter's reputation has been badly damaged.
Who is responsible for that and who decides whether he is vindicated or not has been hotly debated in the court of public opinion.He has not been charged with any crime.

Many have argued that he is entitled to the presumption of innocence, but there are no criminal proceedings or investigations to warrant a challenge to his innocence.Yet the public was informed by the media that an investigation was being sought into the alleged rape of a 16-year-old girl by a senior cabinet minister when he was 17.
The alleged victim, "Kate", is now deceased.
Porter identified himself in a news conference as the minister in question and denied the accusation absolutely.Kate did not bring any civil proceedings.
She might have claimed damages for assault and battery.
There is a six-year limitation period for such a claim and it was statute barred many years ago.
However, the law changed more recently in NSW (the location of the alleged rape) to allow a claim for child sexual abuse where the person was under 18.
The action is not subject to any limitation period.
Kate's estate is entitled to bring any such claim on her behalf.

No such action has been brought.The accusation came to public attention after an anonymous letter was sent to the Prime Minister urging him to set up an "independent inquiry" to investigate the alleged rape.
The issue descended into confusion over whether such an inquiry would be contrary to the criminal law (and for that matter the civil law) and a challenge to the "rule of law".
This confusion remains.Each of the processes available is subject to the rule of law and differing standards of proof.

Criminal law requires the highest standard that the accusation be proved "beyond reasonable doubt", while the civil law requires it to be proved on the "balance of probabilities", with such a serious accusation requiring clear or cogent proof.Inquiries into the fitness of a person to occupy or remain in a position are often established relevant to their employment or membership of a team or group.
Their terms of reference are usually determined by the relevant employment contract or membership agreements.

They are usually required to be conducted subject to due process/natural justice, with fairness necessarily implied.However, such an inquiry cannot ordinarily subpoena documents or "compel" witnesses to give evidence.

Such inquiries may therefore be handicapped and their direction can subtly change from investigation into the truth of the complaint to the impact of the accusation on the reputation of the employer or club.Porter is not an employee or a member of a group of that kind.

Under the Westminster system, ministers have voluntarily resigned on losing the confidence of their prime minister or parliament.The alleged rape did not occur during Porter's time as Attorney-General.

Yet it has been suggested that as he must be a "fit and proper" person to be the first law officer, and while ever he stands accused of serious criminal conduct, he is not fit and proper to remain Attorney-General.

That is a circular argument without merit.The accusation alone does not make him unfit for that post, but it does damage his reputation and harms the confidence and respect he previously enjoyed - and will continue to do so as long as it remains without conclusion.Porter has sought to challenge the accusation through defamation proceedings against the ABC to "nail the lie".

The meaning of what the ABC published will likely be the subject of dispute, but the impression conveyed to the ordinary reasonable person is tested in defamation law by an artificial construct at three different levels of seriousness: Whether there are grounds for an investigation into the conduct alleged;whether there is a reasonable belief he committed the conduct alleged; and whether he is guilty of the conduct alleged.In these times of social media, the public has the tendency to leap to a conclusion about guilt without caring for the presumption of innocence.

That makes a media report about the accusation very prejudicial to the accused.A minister can be suspended or dismissed for any reason by a prime minister, but it would be arbitrary and unreasonable to act on mere accusation alone.Scott Morrison could refer the decision to a statutory inquiry with powers of compulsion, but that would take time and may not provide a conclusion beyond that the accusation is incapable of being proved on the available evidence.Time is of the essence in politics and brand damage is the key.

The Prime Minister may have to act not on proof or otherwise of the accusation but on the basis of how Porter's predicament, affects the reputation of the government.The voters will decide that at the next election.The Prime Minister has the call - and it appears likely he is about to make it.Patrick George is a senior partner atKennedys and author of Defamation in Australia (3rd edition).

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

Who is responsible for that and who decides whether he is vindicated or not has been hotly debated in the court of public opinion.He has not been charged with any crime.
